question_details.query: What evidence exists for the effectiveness of different strategies to combat white-nose syndrome in bats?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence for the effectiveness of strategies to combat white-nose syndrome in bats is limited. Only probiotic bacterium treatment has been studied experimentally. Two randomized, controlled studies found that treating little brown bats with a probiotic bacterium increased survival in some contexts (within cages in a laboratory in Canada, and for free-flying bats in the USA), but had no significant effect on survival for caged bats in a mine. Disease symptoms were reduced when treatment occurred at the time of infection, but worsened when treatment was administered 21 days prior to infection. No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of other commonly proposed strategies, including breeding bats in captivity to supplement populations, treating hibernacula environments to reduce pathogen reservoirs, decontaminating clothing and equipment to prevent pathogen spread, or culling infected bats - meaning their effectiveness remains unassessed.

question_details.query: To mitigate the impact of road and railway developments, what structures can be installed to help bats cross safely?

summary_details.relevant_summary: To help bats cross roads and railways safely, various structures can be installed including bat gantries or bat bridges (action ID 978), overpasses (action ID 977), green bridges (action ID 979), underpasses or culverts (action ID 976), and hop-overs (action ID 980). Evidence shows that green bridges were used by 97% of bats crossing a road in one UK study (action ID 979). However, bat gantries may be less effective, with studies finding that fewer bats used bat gantries than crossed the road below at traffic height, and some gantries were not used at all (action ID 978). Overpasses showed mixed results with some bat species using them but many still crossing the road below at traffic height or other locations (action ID 977). Underpasses and culverts were used by bats in varying proportions across multiple studies, with species adapted to cluttered habitats using smaller culverts more than those adapted to open habitats (action ID 976). There is currently no evidence available for hop-overs as no studies have evaluated their effectiveness (action ID 980).

To mitigate impacts from onshore wind farms, what are the most effective operational adjustments to turbines to reduce bat fatalities?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence from action documents shows several effective operational adjustments to reduce bat fatalities at onshore wind farms. Increasing the wind speed at which turbines become operational ('cut-in speed') was the most extensively studied approach, with 10 of 12 replicated studies in the USA and Canada finding this resulted in fewer bat fatalities (Action 1960). Preventing turbine blades from turning at low wind speeds through 'feathering' also proved effective, with five of six studies showing reduced bat fatalities (Action 970). Automatically reducing turbine blade rotation when bat activity is predicted to be high was effective in both German and US studies, significantly reducing fatalities for all bat species combined and for individual species (Action 971). Slowing turbine blade rotation at low wind speeds was found to reduce bat fatalities in a Canadian study (Action 2939). Ultrasonic deterrents showed mixed results, with some studies finding 21-51% fewer bat fatalities in the first year, but inconsistent results in subsequent years and across different bat species (Action 968). No studies were found evaluating the effects of removing turbine lighting on bat fatalities (Action 969).

How effective are different public education and engagement strategies for improving bat conservation outcomes?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence regarding the effectiveness of public education and engagement strategies for bat conservation is limited. No studies were found that evaluated educating the public to improve bat perception and behavior (action 1000), or educating farmers, land managers and communities about bat benefits for habitat management (action 2040). However, one UK study on engaging farmers and landowners to manage land for bats (action 1936) showed promising results: during a five-year project, the overall population of greater horseshoe bats at four maternity roosts increased, and 77 bat-related management agreements covering approximately 6,536 ha of land were established. Regarding general public awareness campaigns (action 162), a review of programs in the USA and Canada argued that education alone was not sufficient to change behavior, although it served as a necessary catalytic factor for economic incentives and law enforcement. While education campaigns for other wildlife groups (reptiles) have shown measurable conservation benefits including increased abundance (Philippine crocodiles), reduced poaching (leatherback turtle nests), and decreased human-caused mortality (Philippine crocodiles), similar evidence is lacking specifically for bat conservation initiatives.

question_details.query: Besides avoiding illumination entirely, what alternative lighting strategies can be used to minimize disturbance to bats?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Besides avoiding illumination entirely, several alternative lighting strategies can minimize disturbance to bats. Red lighting has shown promise, with studies finding that red lighting resulted in higher activity for some bat species compared to white or green lighting, and more soprano pipistrelles emerged from roosts when lit with red light compared to white light (action IDs: 2021). Using ultraviolet filters on lights can also be beneficial, with one study finding that hedges lit with ultraviolet filtered lights had higher soprano pipistrelle activity than those lit with unfiltered light (action ID: 1020). Low intensity lighting is another strategy, with one controlled study in caves finding that low intensity white lights or red lights resulted in fewer bat flights than full white lighting (action ID: 1994). Directing lighting away from bat access points or habitats is recommended as a strategy, though no studies have yet evaluated its effectiveness (action ID: 2019). Using 'warm white' LED lights rather than 'cool' LED lights has been suggested as a potential strategy, though no studies have evaluated this approach (action ID: 2020).

question_details.query: To protect bats from the impacts of mining operations, what actions can be taken during and after mine closure and reclamation?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on available evidence, several actions can be considered for protecting bats during and after mine closure and reclamation. One study found that modifying the microclimate of an abandoned mine by closing a man-made entrance resulted in a greater number of bats hibernating within the mine (Action ID: 1964). Another study showed that restoring bat foraging habitat at ex-quarry sites can increase bat activity, with gravel-sand pits having higher overall bat activity 10 years after restoration compared to before or during quarrying (Action ID: 2286). However, no studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of retaining bat access points following mine closures, excluding bats from roosts prior to mine reclamation, or retaining access points to caves (Action IDs: 1962, 1961, 1990), meaning their effectiveness remains unassessed in the scientific literature.

question_details.query: What are the most effective legislative actions for protecting bats and their habitats?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the available evidence, legally protecting bat habitats (action ID 2045) is the most documented legislative action for bat conservation. Five studies evaluated this approach and found positive effects on bat populations, with higher bat activity and abundance observed in protected areas compared to unprotected areas across Europe and India. One study found that 10 of 11 bat species distributions significantly overlapped with designated protection areas. However, no studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of other legislative measures such as legally protecting bat species, enforcing existing habitat protection legislation, controlling bat hunting through legislation, regulating bat guano harvesting, or enforcing anti-trafficking regulations.

question_details.query: For bat conservation related to transportation infrastructure, what are the documented benefits and limitations of providing or retaining roosts in bridges and culverts?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence from action documents shows mixed results for bat roost conservation in transportation infrastructure. For creating roost spaces in bridges, one review study found that spaces created to replace those lost during bridge works were recolonized by bats in similar or greater numbers at four of eight sites (Action ID: 1967). When maintaining existing roosts during bridge work, a before-and-after study in Ireland found that a Daubenton's bat maternity colony continued roosting in similar numbers after crevices were retained during repairs (Action ID: 1966). However, another review found that while Yuma myotis and Mexican free-tailed bats recolonised most maintained roosts in similar numbers, pallid bats did not return after bridge replacement works (Action ID: 1966). Providing alternative roosts showed poor results - bat houses provided during bridge replacement were used by fewer bats than original roosts at one site and not used at all at three sites (Action ID: 2942). No studies were found evaluating the effects of excluding bats from roosts during maintenance or changing the timing of maintenance work (Action IDs: 2941, 2940).

question_details.query: How does the evidence for managing existing hedgerows for bats compare to that for planting new ones?

summary_details.relevant_summary: The evidence for managing existing hedgerows for bats significantly outweighs the evidence for planting new hedgerows. For existing hedgerow management, two UK studies evaluated managing hedges specifically for bats, finding that hedges trimmed ≥3 years prior had more bat species recorded and higher activity of two bat species compared to hedges trimmed during the previous winter (Action ID 1943). One study also found that up to one fifth of lesser horseshoe bats flew along an artificial hedgerow used to divert them to safe crossing points (Action ID 981). In contrast, for planting new hedgerows, one study found no evidence that planting new hedges has been evaluated for bats (Action ID 1942), and another found no studies evaluating creating new unlit bat commuting routes using planting (Action ID 2034). Similarly, no studies were found evaluating managing hedgerows to benefit wildlife on farmland in general (Action ID 2382). The evidence base is clearly weighted toward management of existing hedgerows rather than planting new ones.

question_details.query: What actions can be taken to provide bat roosting sites in trees where natural cavities are lacking?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Several actions can be taken to provide bat roosting sites in trees where natural cavities are lacking:

Creating artificial hollows and cracks in trees (Action 2047): One replicated study in Australia found that eight of 16 artificial hollows cut into trees with two different entrance designs were used by roosting long-eared bats.

Providing bat boxes (Action 1024): Forty-four studies found that bats used bat boxes installed in various habitats including forest, woodland, farmland, pasture, wetlands, and urban areas. A review of 109 studies found that 72 bat species used bat boxes, with 18 species commonly using them and 31 species using them as maternity roosts. Bat box design matters - studies found bats preferred black boxes over grey, white or wooden boxes, and occupancy varied with orientation, height, and position (on buildings vs trees).

Reinstating bat roosts in felled tree trunks (Action 2048): One before-and-after study in the UK found that a roost reinstated by attaching the felled tree trunk to a nearby tree continued to be used by common noctule bats as a maternity roost.

Creating alternative roosts within developments (Action 949): Eleven studies evaluated creating alternative bat roosts within developments. Some studies found bats used purpose-built roosts after original roosts were destroyed, while others found lower usage than the original roosts.

Providing bat boxes, bat grilles, and improvements to roosts (Action 95): No evidence was captured for the effects of these actions, indicating more research is needed.

question_details.query: How does the evidence for legally protecting bat habitats compare to legally protecting bats during development activities?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
The evidence for legally protecting bat habitats shows more positive outcomes compared to legally protecting bats during development activities. For habitat protection (Action ID 2045), five studies found that legally protected sites had greater bat species richness and higher bat activity/abundance compared to unprotected sites. One study found that distributions of 10 of 11 bat species overlapped with protected areas significantly more than by chance.

In contrast, legal protection during development activities (Action ID 1935) showed more mixed results. Four UK studies found that while development licences for bats increased, 81% of licensees did not conduct required post-development monitoring. Licensed activities during building developments had negative impacts, with 68% of roosts being destroyed. Only 31-67% of compensation roosts provided under licence were used by bats, and new alternative roosts were four times less likely to be used than retained roosts. Retaining existing roosts and access points during development (Action ID 947) showed better outcomes, with two-thirds of retained roosts being used after development, and retained roosts were more likely to be used than newly created roosts.

In the agricultural sector, what are the observed effects of organic farming systems compared to conventional farming on bat populations?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Twelve studies evaluated the effects of using organic farming instead of conventional farming on bat populations, with eight studies in Europe, two in the USA, one in Canada, and one in Chile. Community response was mixed: one study found no difference in bat species composition, while five of seven studies found no difference in species richness/diversity between organic and non-organic farms; the remaining two studies found more bat species on organic farms. Population response also varied: five of nine studies found no difference in overall bat activity or common pipistrelle activity, while four studies found higher overall bat activity, bat feeding activity, Brazilian free-tailed bat activity, and activity of four of seven bat species on organic farms. Two UK studies found higher activity of Myotis species over water and rivers on organic farms, and one French study found higher activity for two of three bat species over organic fields compared to conventionally managed fields.

question_details.query: What factors are associated with the successful use of artificial bat roosts by bats?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the evidence from action documents, several factors are associated with successful artificial bat roost use. Microclimate management is crucial, with one study showing increased bat numbers after artificial roosts were modified to reduce internal temperatures (action 2052). Bat boxes showed variable occupancy rates across 44 studies, with 31 species using them as maternity roosts, though only 18 species used them commonly (action 1024). Design factors significantly influence success: black bat boxes were used more than grey, white, or wooden alternatives (action 1024), and bats showed preferences for specific designs including multi-compartment boxes and concrete versus wooden materials. Position matters - bat box orientation and sunlight exposure affected occupancy, with boxes on buildings having higher occupancy than those on trees (action 1024). Height effects varied between studies, while location type influenced success, with farm forestry sites showing higher occupancy than native forest (action 1024). Artificial caves and hibernacula demonstrated gradual adoption, with one study showing increasing bat numbers over nine years after construction (action 2049). Success was enhanced when artificial roosts were installed in areas where bats were known to roost previously (action 1024). Tree hollow creation showed promise, with eight of 16 artificial tree hollows being used by long-eared bats (action 2047), suggesting that mimicking natural roost characteristics improves acceptance.

summary_details.relevant_summary: Several conservation actions have been identified for combating white-nose syndrome in bats. The only action with scientific evidence is treating bats with probiotic bacteria, which showed increased survival in free-flying bats and reduced disease symptoms when administered at the time of infection in laboratory studies (Action ID: 2008). Other proposed actions include culling infected bats (Action ID: 1012), vaccinating bats against the pathogen (Action ID: 1011), breeding bats in captivity to supplement wild populations (Action ID: 2009), restricting human access to bat caves (Action ID: 1010), treating hibernacula environments to reduce pathogen reservoirs (Action ID: 2007), and decontaminating clothing and equipment after cave entry (Action ID: 2006). However, no scientific studies have evaluated the effectiveness of these latter actions.

What is the extent of evidence for actions to mitigate pollution from agricultural sources to benefit bats?

summary_details.relevant_summary: The evidence base for actions to mitigate pollution from agricultural sources to benefit bats is currently extremely limited. No studies were found that evaluated the effects on bat populations of preventing pollution from agricultural land or forestry from entering watercourses (Action 2015), changing effluent treatments used in agriculture and forestry (Action 1016), planting riparian buffer strips (Action 2016), or managing ditches to benefit bats (Action 1944). One study evaluated retaining riparian buffers on agricultural land (Action 2284), finding no difference in pipistrelle activity between waterways with vegetation buffers on agri-environment scheme farms and conventional farms. This indicates that for the primary interventions aimed at reducing agricultural pollution - preventing agricultural runoff, modifying effluent treatments, and establishing vegetated buffers - there is currently no evidence demonstrating their effectiveness for bat conservation.

question_details.query: What design and placement factors influence the successful use of bat boxes by bats?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Research on bat box effectiveness has identified several key design and placement factors that influence successful use by bats. Design factors include: color (black boxes used more than grey, white, or wooden boxes), size (larger bat boxes showed higher occupancy rates), material (concrete boxes had higher occupancy than wooden ones; resin boxes became occupied more quickly than wood), compartment configuration (two-compartment boxes occupied by more bats than one-compartment during breeding season), and specific design variants (rocket boxes preferred over wooden boxes or bark-mimic roosts by Indiana bats). Placement factors include: orientation and sun exposure (affects occupancy with orientation and sunlight amount being important), height (studies show mixed results with some finding height affects occupancy while others found no effect), location type (higher occupancy on buildings than trees in some studies), habitat context (farm forestry sites vs native forest, pine vs mixed deciduous stands), and prior bat presence (higher occupancy in areas where bats were known to roost before installing boxes). Additional factors include the number of boxes installed (greater numbers across a site increase occupancy likelihood) and microclimate management (modifying roost temperatures can increase bat numbers). However, 22 studies found bats occupying less than half of provided boxes (0-49%), while nine studies found occupancy rates above 50% (54-100%), indicating that even optimally designed and placed boxes may not always be used.

question_details.query: How do different types of purpose-built road crossing structures compare in effectiveness for bats?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the available evidence, different types of bat crossing structures show varying levels of effectiveness. Green bridges appear to be the most effective, with one study finding that a green bridge was used by 97% of bats crossing a road (Action ID 979). Underpasses and culverts have been studied most extensively, with eight studies showing that bats use them in varying proportions depending on factors such as underpass type, height, road width, and surrounding landscape features (Action ID 976). Bat species adapted to cluttered habitats used small culverts and underpasses more than species adapted to open or edge habitats. Overpasses show mixed results, with studies indicating that while some bat species use them, up to three-quarters of bats still cross the road below at traffic height or at other nearby locations - vegetated overpasses with planters were used by two-thirds of crossing bats, while unvegetated overpasses were not used at all (Action ID 977). Bat gantries or bat bridges appear to be the least effective, with studies finding that fewer bats used them than crossed the road below at traffic height, and some gantries were not used at all (Action ID 978). No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of hop-overs for bats (Action ID 980).

question_details.query: For arid regions, what is the evidence on the effectiveness of creating or managing water sources to support bat populations?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence from five studies shows that creating artificial water sources can be effective for supporting bat populations in arid regions. Five replicated studies across Israel, the USA, Germany, South Africa and Mexico found that bat activity (relative abundance) was similar or higher over reservoirs, waste water treatment pools, heliponds, drainage ditches, retention ponds and farm/cattle ponds compared to natural wetlands, vineyards, forest or grassland/crops (Action 959). For livestock water troughs specifically, two studies in the USA demonstrated that management matters - removing livestock modifications resulted in bats drinking more frequently and approaching troughs fewer times before successfully drinking (Action 1951). One study in Portugal found that small dam reservoirs created greater activity for four bat species than the streams feeding into them (Action 1997). However, no studies were found evaluating the effects of managing natural water bodies to prevent desiccation in arid areas (Action 2027), indicating a knowledge gap in this area.
summary_statements: Evidence from five studies shows that creating artificial water sources can be effective for supporting bat populations in arid regions.

question_details.query: In agricultural landscapes, which farming systems are most beneficial for bat populations?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the evidence from action documents, organic farming systems (action ID 961) show mixed but generally positive effects on bat populations. Twelve studies found that organic farming resulted in higher bat activity and species richness compared to conventional farming in some cases, with five of nine studies showing higher overall bat activity on organic farms. Agroforestry systems that retain or plant native trees and shrubs amongst crops (action ID 963) showed varied results across eight studies, with some finding higher bat species diversity and abundance in plantations with varied shade cover. Reducing pesticide, herbicide and fertiliser use (action ID 2013) demonstrated positive effects in four studies, with farms using fewer chemicals showing higher bat activity and species diversity. Managing hedges specifically for bats (action ID 1943) showed limited but positive effects in two UK studies, with hedges trimmed less frequently having more bat species and higher activity. However, there is currently no evidence available for several potentially beneficial practices including increasing semi-natural habitat (action ID 1938), retaining remnant forest (action ID 1947), managing ditches for bats (action ID 1944), practicing integrated farm management (action ID 169), or planting in-field trees (action ID 1946).

question_details.query: What are the outcomes and success rates associated with ex-situ bat conservation actions like captive breeding and rehabilitation?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on action documents, eight studies evaluated captive breeding effects, showing that 6-100% of female bats captured in the wild successfully conceived, gave birth and reared young in captivity across studies in the USA, UK, Italy and Brazil. Two studies found that two of five and two of three bats born in captivity successfully gave birth to live young. Seven studies found that 20-100% of bat pups born in captivity survived from 10 days to adulthood. However, no studies evaluated the effects of releasing captive-bred bats back to the wild. Four studies evaluated rehabilitation of injured/orphaned bats. One study in Brazil found two hand-reared orphaned greater spear-nosed bats survived over three months in captivity and reached normal species size after 60 days. Two studies in the UK and Italy found 70-90% of hand-reared pipistrelle bats survived 4-14 days after wild release, with six of 21 bats joining wild colonies. One UK study found 13% of ringed hand-reared pipistrelle bats were found alive in bat boxes 38 days to four years after release. Another UK study found bats that flew in large flight cages for longer periods survived longer and were more active after release. Importantly, no studies evaluated breeding bats specifically to supplement wild populations affected by white-nose syndrome.
